item.title: By: SteveO
item.dc:creator: SteveO
item.content:encoded:
I liked the range of areas that this quiz encompassed.

From try catch to triggers.

item.title: By: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.dc:creator: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.description: I got the one that of all people should not have gotten wrong. It's a good quiz though. Wonder if you can submit quiz's to brads weekly challenge http://www.databaseweekly.com/ He's always edition and version orientated though
item.content:encoded: I got the one that of all people should not have gotten wrong. It’s a good quiz though. Wonder if you can submit quiz’s to brads weekly challenge http://www.databaseweekly.com/ He’s always edition and version orientated though

item.title: By: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.dc:creator: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.description: I liked the quiz, but I cheated and ran some samples in SSMS.
item.content:encoded: I liked the quiz, but I cheated and ran some samples in SSMS.

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.content:encoded:
you mean 8000 not 2000 right?

Run this now ðŸ™‚

DECLARE @v VARCHAR(MAX)

SELECT @v =REPLICATE(convert(varchar(max),’a’),20000)

SELECT LEN(@v)

item.title: By: traingamer
item.dc:creator: traingamer
item.content:encoded:
I like #8. Since ‘a’ is not a VARCHAR(MAX), REPLICATE has a limit of 2000
characters.
This would give the results some might expect:
DECLARE @v VARCHAR(MAX)
DECLARE @a VARCHAR(MAX)
select @a = ‘a’
SELECT @v =REPLICATE(@a,20000)

SELECT LEN(@v)

item.dc:creator: Natas
item.description: What is the deal with number 4? That is bizarre. Guess I will have to wait till tomorrow to find out
